description: 2020 JUN 05-- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Drug Daily-- Investigators discuss new findings in Cancer. According to news reporting out of Munster, Germany, by NewsRx editors, research stated,“ In circulation, cancer cells induce platelet activation, leading to the formation of a cancer cell-encircling platelet cloak which facilitates each step of...
text:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Drug
Daily \-- Investigators discuss new findings in Cancer. According to news
reporting out of Munster, Germany, by NewsRx editors, research stated, "In
circulation, cancer cells induce platelet activation, leading to the formation
of a cancer cell-encircling platelet cloak which facilitates each step of the
metastatic cascade. Since cancer patients treated with the anticoagulant
heparin showed reduced metastasis rates and improved survival, it is supposed
that heparin suppresses the cloak's formation by inhibiting the interaction
between platelet's adhesion molecule P-selectin with its ligands on cancer
cells."

Funders for this research include Cells-in-Motion Cluster of Excellence,
Doctoral training program MedK Munster.

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from University
Munster, "To quantify this heparin effect, we developed a single-cell force
spectroscopy approach and quantified the adhesion (maximum adhesion force [F ]
and detachment work [W ]) between platelets and human non-small cell lung
cancer cells (A549). A configuration was used in which A549 cells were glued
to tipless cantilevers and force-distance (F-D) curves were recorded on a
layer of activated platelets. The concentration-response relationship was
determined for heparin at concentrations between 1 and 100 U/mL. Sigmoid dose-
response fit revealed half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC ) values of
8.01 U/mL (F ) and 6.46 U/mL (W ) and a maximum decrease of the adhesion by
37.5% (F ) and 38.42% (W ). The effect of heparin on P-selectin was tested
using anti-P-selectin antibodies alone and in combination with heparin. Adding
heparin after antibody treatment resulted in an additional reduction of 9.52%
(F ) and 7.12% (W ). Together, we quantified heparin's antimetastatic effect
and proved that it predominantly is related to the blockage of P-selectin."

According to the news editors, the research concluded: "Our approach
represents a valuable method to investigate the adhesion of platelets to
cancer cells and the efficiency of substances to block this interaction."

For more information on this research see: Quantification of heparin's
antimetastatic effect by single-cell force spectroscopy. _Journal of Molecular
Recognition_ , 2020;():. _Journal of Molecular Recognition_ can be contacted
at: John Wiley & Sons LTD, the Atrium, Southern Gate, Chichester PO19 8SQ, W
Sussex, England. (Wiley-Blackwell - <http://www.wiley.com/>; Journal of
Molecular Recognition \-
<http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1099-1352>)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by
contacting H. Schillers, Institute of Physiology II, University Munster,
Munster, Germany.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is:
<https://doi.org/10.1002/jmr.2854>. This DOI is a link to an online electronic
document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source
for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the _Journal of Molecular Recognition_ is:
John Wiley & Sons LTD, the Atrium, Southern Gate, Chichester PO19 8SQ, W
Sussex, England.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around
the world.)

title: Study Findings from University Munster Provide New Insights into Cancer (Quantification of heparin’s antimetastatic effect by single-cell force spectroscopy): Cancer
html:
2020 JUN 05 (NewsRx) -- By a News Reporter-Staff News Editor at NewsRx Drug Daily -- Investigators discuss new findings in Cancer. According to news reporting out of Munster, Germany, by NewsRx editors, research stated, “In circulation, cancer cells induce platelet activation, leading to the formation of a cancer cell-encircling platelet cloak which facilitates each step of the metastatic cascade. Since cancer patients treated with the anticoagulant heparin showed reduced metastasis rates and improved survival, it is supposed that heparin suppresses the cloak’s formation by inhibiting the interaction between platelet’s adhesion molecule P-selectin with its ligands on cancer cells.”

Funders for this research include Cells-in-Motion Cluster of Excellence, Doctoral training program MedK Munster.

Our news journalists obtained a quote from the research from University Munster, “To quantify this heparin effect, we developed a single-cell force spectroscopy approach and quantified the adhesion (maximum adhesion force [F ] and detachment work [W ]) between platelets and human non-small cell lung cancer cells (A549). A configuration was used in which A549 cells were glued to tipless cantilevers and force-distance (F-D) curves were recorded on a layer of activated platelets. The concentration-response relationship was determined for heparin at concentrations between 1 and 100 U/mL. Sigmoid dose-response fit revealed half-maximal inhibitory concentration (IC ) values of 8.01 U/mL (F ) and 6.46 U/mL (W ) and a maximum decrease of the adhesion by 37.5% (F ) and 38.42% (W ). The effect of heparin on P-selectin was tested using anti-P-selectin antibodies alone and in combination with heparin. Adding heparin after antibody treatment resulted in an additional reduction of 9.52% (F ) and 7.12% (W ). Together, we quantified heparin’s antimetastatic effect and proved that it predominantly is related to the blockage of P-selectin.”

According to the news editors, the research concluded: “Our approach represents a valuable method to investigate the adhesion of platelets to cancer cells and the efficiency of substances to block this interaction.”

For more information on this research see: Quantification of heparin’s antimetastatic effect by single-cell force spectroscopy. Journal of Molecular Recognition, 2020;():. Journal of Molecular Recognition can be contacted at: John Wiley & Sons LTD, the Atrium, Southern Gate, Chichester PO19 8SQ, W Sussex, England. (Wiley-Blackwell - http://www.wiley.com/; Journal of Molecular Recognition - http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/journal/10.1002/(ISSN)1099-1352)

Our news journalists report that additional information may be obtained by contacting H. Schillers, Institute of Physiology II, University Munster, Munster, Germany.

The direct object identifier (DOI) for that additional information is: https://doi.org/10.1002/jmr.2854. This DOI is a link to an online electronic document that is either free or for purchase, and can be your direct source for a journal article and its citation.

Publisher contact information for the Journal of Molecular Recognition is: John Wiley & Sons LTD, the Atrium, Southern Gate, Chichester PO19 8SQ, W Sussex, England.

(Our reports deliver fact-based news of research and discoveries from around the world.)
